page.title: 04SETTLEMENT SITE 1, HOCKLIFFE
page.content: Hockliffe's{earliest settlement}began high on a hill commanding a splendid view of the surrounding area with a water supply from the nearby{springs} and maybe even{Clipstone Brook,}a tributary of the{River Ouzel.} By{1086}according to the{Domesday Book the settlement boasted a{population}of about{120.}During the early{Middle } {Ages}a church was built on the hill and the houses spread around it forming a{nucleated village.}Less than a mile away the{Roman Watling Street} ran between{Chester(Deva)}and{London } {(Londinium).}Settlement began to grow up along the old Roman road towards the end of the Middle Ages. As a result many of the houses around the church were{deserted}and fell into {ruin.}Grass and weeds grew over the ruins and bumps and mounds were all that remained of{Medieval Hockliffe.}
